item.title: Where Is Germany in the Ukraine Standoff? Its Allies Wonder.
item.description: Germany’s allies have begun to question what price Berlin is prepared to pay to deter Russia, and even its reliability as an ally, as it wavers on tough measures.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The German chancellor, Olaf Scholz, in Berlin this month. Mr. Scholz’s Social Democrats have traditionally favored a policy of working with the Russians.

item.title: As ISIS Resurges, US is Drawn Back Into the Fray
item.description: “ISIS is not over”: Attacks in Syria and Iraq make clear that the militants have lost neither their will to fight nor their ability to do so.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and Ben Hubbard
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An American military vehicle patrolling on Monday in Hasaka, Syria.

item.title: After Coup in Burkina Faso, Protesters Turn to Russia for Help
item.description: Fed up with the failure of their government, and France, to stop the violence caused by militants, some citizens now call for Russia to intervene.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crowds celebrating the military takeover in a plaza in Ouagadougou, the capital, brandished Russian flags and signs that said, “No to France.”

item.title: Heavy Snow Strands Motorists in Greece and Turkey
item.description: In areas more used to dealing with extreme heat, blizzard conditions caused chaos on roads and at airports.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Drivers were stuck on the main Athens ring road on Monday. The heavy snowfall lasted more than 12 hours.

item.title: Leprosy Hospital Offers Healing, and a Haven, to the Shunned
item.description: While leprosy is now easily treated, those who have the disease are still often ostracized. But they’re always welcome at this refuge in India, a nation that records over half the world’s cases.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patients watching TV in the women’s ward of the Sivananda Rehabilitation Home in Hyderabad, India, in December. The free hospital has been treating leprosy for six decades.

item.title: U.S. to Bolster Europe’s Fuel Supply to Blunt Threat of Russian Cutoff
item.description: Many European officials suspect President Vladimir V. Putin instigated the crisis in the winter in part to leverage his threat to turn off Russian fuel sales to Europe.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: A construction site of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, near the town of Kingisepp, Russia, in 2019. The country provides about one-third of the gas and crude oil imported by the European Union.

item.title: Kazakhstan’s Longtime Leader Is Gone, but Still Seemingly Everywhere
item.description: Nursultan Nazarbayev, the autocratic former president, all but vanished after violent protests this month. But with his legacy so pervasive, will anything change?
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Playing next to a statue of Kazakhstan’s former president, Nursultan Nazarbayev, in Nur-Sultan, the capital that was renamed in his honor, this month.

item.title: For Ukrainian Soldiers, a Nervous Guessing Game on the Front
item.description: Given Russia’s penchant for misdirection, it’s unclear how a military incursion would start. And that keeps the Ukrainian troops on edge.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in a trench on the frontline on Monday in Popasna, Ukraine.

item.title: How Ukraine’s Leaders Are Responding to Russian Threat
item.description: The ‘‘stay calm” posture has left analysts guessing about its leadership’s motivation, but some say that after eight years of war, the country simply calculates the risks differently.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A satellite image showing Russian tanks and artillery tents this month near Voronezh, in southwestern Russia.

item.title: Why Is North Korea Suddenly Launching So Many Missiles?
item.description: Experience has shown Kim Jong-un that saber-rattling is the best way to get Washington’s attention, especially when global affairs are already in a precarious state.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency/Korea News Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo provided by the North Korean government showing what it said was a test-fire of a tactical guided missile on Jan. 17.

item.title: Guatemalan Militia Men Get 30 Years for Wartime Atrocities
item.description: Five members of a pro-government paramilitary group were convicted of crimes against humanity that were committed against five Indigenous women during the country’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez and Jody García
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Women who identify themselves as victims of human rights violations during Guatemala’s civil war applauding outside the Supreme Court in Guatemala City on Monday after the sentencing of five former paramilitary members.

item.title: Heavy Snow Strands Motorists in Greece and Turkey
item.description: In areas more used to dealing with extreme heat, blizzard conditions caused chaos on roads and at airports.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Drivers were stuck on the main Athens ring road on Monday. The heavy snowfall lasted more than 12 hours.

item.title: U.S. Navy Fighter Jet Accident in South China Sea Injures 7
item.description: The military said it was investigating the cause of a “landing mishap” during routine operations.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Petty Officer 1st Class Arthurgwain Marquez/U.S. Navy, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo provided by the U.S. Navy of the aircraft carrier Carl Vinson in 2018.

item.title: U.K. Police Say They Are Investigating Downing Street Lockdown Parties
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has come under fire over revelations that he and his staff attended parties while the country was in a coronavirus lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The front pages of British newspapers in London earlier this month.

item.title: How Boris Johnson Could Lose His Job as U.K. Prime Minister: Latest Details
item.description: Parties while Britain was under Covid lockdown have pushed Mr. Johnson into two apologies and prompted a police investigation. Here’s a guide to how he could be forced out, or fight on.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle

item.title: How Scott Morrison Lost Control of His WeChat Account
item.description: A Chinese electronics company said it had bought the WeChat account legitimately, but some Australian officials said it was hijacked, and urged a boycott.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and John Liu
item.media:description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia got a WeChat account in 2019, but his team has not had access to it since last year.

item.title: Russia Steps Up Propaganda War Amid Ukraine Tensions
item.description: The disinformation campaign includes claims that NATO and Ukrainian forces are preparing to attack Russian speakers in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Russian soldiers in the country’s Rostov region, near Ukraine, this month. Russia has produced a steady stream of disinformation about Ukraine since 2014, according to American intelligence officials.

item.title: Dozens Are Reported Missing After Boat Capsizes Off Florida Coast
item.description: The boat, which left the Bahamas on Saturday with 40 people on board, was most likely part of a “human smuggling venture,” the Coast Guard said. One passenger was rescued.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:description: A man was rescued after he was found straddling the hull of a boat that capsized near the Fort Pierce Inlet on Florida’s Atlantic Coast, the U.S. Coast Guard said.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia’s Military Drills
item.description: The Kremlin blamed the U.S. for ramping up tensions.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Alexei Ivanov/Russian Defense Ministry Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo released on Tuesday by the Russian Defense Ministry Press Service of Russian soldiers during a military exercise at the Golovenki training ground in the Moscow region.

item.title: ‘Compartment No. 6’ Review: Strangers on a Russian Train
item.description: A young Finnish woman embarks on a journey of self-discovery that takes her (and you) through richly detailed and surprising terrain.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Frank Dutton, Who Took On Apartheid’s Crimes, Dies at 72
item.description: One of South Africa’s most lauded police officials, he investigated crimes by the authorities and dug into cold cases from the days of white nationalist rule.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Neil Young posts and removes a letter demanding Spotify remove his music.
item.description: “They can have Rogan or Young,” Neil Young wrote to his management team and record label in a letter that he has since removed from his website, according to Rolling Stone. “Not both.”
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Neil Young called on Spotify to remove his music from the streaming service.

item.title: Coronavirus Outbreak Is Reported on Aid Ship Bound for Tonga
item.description: Twenty-three people aboard the Australian ship have tested positive for the virus, prompting concerns that it could spread to Tonga. The volcano-stricken island has reported only one case during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Twenty-three people aboard the H.M.A.S. Adelaide were in isolation after an outbreak was reported on the ship.

item.title: How Do You Pronounce Kyiv?
item.description: “When I see American media, it’s always different, it’s always new, always a surprise,” said a teacher of Ukrainian and Russian languages.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor and Karen Zraick
item.media:description: At Sophia Square in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Israeli Experts Recommend Offering a Fourth Vaccine Dose to People Age 18 and Over
item.description: The Health Ministry cited early signs that a fourth shot might help protect against serious illness, but has yet to approve the panel’s recommendation.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Receiving a fourth coronavirus vaccine dose in Tel Mond, Israel, this month.

item.title: Two Covid Americas
item.description: The unvaccinated are less worried than the boosted, according to a poll.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lining up for tests in Salt Lake City.

item.title: C.I.A.-Backed Afghan Fighters Are Still Waiting to Reach U.S.
item.description: Commandos who played a key role in helping American forces are waiting for visas in the United Arab Emirates, and are among the last of the evacuated Afghans to get a chance to reach the United States.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands of Afghans waited outside Kabul’s airport in August as they tried to flee the country. Afghan commandos trained by the C.I.A. provided security at the airport.

item.title: Sue Gray’s Report Could Determine Boris Johnson’s Fate
item.description: Sue Gray, who oversees the British government’s ethics inquiries, will deliver a report on Downing Street parties that could topple the prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson during a coronavirus media briefing in Downing Street, London, on Jan. 4.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: U.S. troops may be deployed to Eastern Europe.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Most of the 8,500 troops would take part in a NATO response force that might soon be activated, John F. Kirby, the Pentagon spokesman, said on Monday.

item.title: War Looms Between Russia and Ukraine, but Diplomatic Options Remain
item.description: Fears of a Russian invasion of Ukraine are growing, but diplomatic options remain.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in a trench on the frontline on Monday in Popasna, Ukraine.

item.title: Omicron Offers Hope Pandemic Could Stabilize, W.H.O. Official Says.
item.description: The rapid spread of the variant means far more people will have some immunity, at least for now, which might bode well this year for highly vaccinated countries in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller and Marc Santora
item.media:description: A Covid-19 intensive care unit in Cremona, Italy, this month.

item.title: At Least 6 Killed in Crush at African Cup Match
item.description: Witnesses said the stadium stewards closed the gates and stopped allowing people in, setting off the crush.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Cameroon fans inside Olembe Stadium on Monday in Yaounde.

item.title: Burkina Faso President Ousted in Military Coup
item.description: Mutinous officers said the public was fed up with President Roch Marc Christian Kaboré because of his inability to stop attacks by Islamist militants.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crowds cheering the military takeover in Ouagadougou, the capital of Burkina Faso, on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Officials Limit Anitbody Treatments That Don’t Work on Omicron
item.description: New and other treatments remain effective but are reaching doctors in quantities that are no match for the Omicron surge.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nurses at Houston Methodist Hospital administering a monoclonal antibody treatment to a Covid-19 patient in September.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: 8,500 Troops on ‘High Alert’
item.description: U.S. and NATO allies make plans in case of Russian military action.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: U.S. soldiers of the NATO Extended Presence Battlegroup participated in a military exercise in Latvia last March.

item.title: Pentagon Puts 8,500 Troops on ‘High Alert’ Amid Ukraine Tensions
item.description: The move signals a shift for the Biden administration as the United States and NATO allies brace for possible Russian military action.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Most of the 8,500 troops would take part in a NATO response force that might soon be activated, John F. Kirby, the Pentagon spokesman, said on Monday.

item.title: Irish Police Investigate Mysterious Death in Post Office
item.description: The police said a man was found dead in a post office where pensions were collected. Witnesses told the Irish media that two men had brought him there to collect his funds.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin

item.title: Italians Vote for a President. Here’s Why It Matters.
item.description: The normally mundane ritual of electing a president every seven years has turned more fateful this year, with Italy’s political stability potentially hanging in the balance.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: If elected, Mario Draghi would be the first prime minister to ascend to the Italian presidency.

item.title: Threatened and Beaten, Afghan Women Defy Taliban With Protests
item.description: The Taliban have begun cracking down harder as women insist on their rights and as Western governments call for reforms.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino and Yaqoob Akbary
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesting for women’s rights under the Taliban in Kabul, Afghanistan, in October.

item.title: Covid setbacks to schooling are ‘nearly insurmountable,’ the U.N. says.
item.description: Many millions of children have “significantly missed out” on the academic learning they would have acquired in the classroom, the United Nations Children’s Fund said in a new report.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eric, left, and Quita Shorty, from Atlanta, are among millions of schoolchildren who have endured extended periods away from the classroom.

item.title: Saad Hariri, Lebanon’s Former Prime Minister, Quits Politics
item.description: He was the leader of the country’s Sunni Muslims, one of the three main sects that share power, and the scion of a prominent political dynasty.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Saad Hariri, the former prime minister of Lebanon, announced his withdrawal from political life on Monday at a news conference in his home in Beirut.

item.title: US Troops Join Kurdish-Led Forces in Assault on Prison Held by ISIS
item.description: The Islamic State seized a prison in Syria to try to free thousands of fellow jihadists and is using hundreds of imprisoned boys as human shields.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: The Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces patrolling Hasaka, Syria, on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Helps Thwart Attack by Yemen Rebels on American Air Base in U.A.E.
item.description: The Houthi rebels fired two missiles at a base in Abu Dhabi where 2,000 Americans are stationed, the latest salvo in their escalating war with a Saudi-led coalition that includes the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: Mona El-Naggar and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Listening to a Houthi spokesman delivering a statement about attacks on Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates in Sanaa, Yemen, on Monday.

item.title: Stowaway Survives Flight to Amsterdam in a Plane's Wheel Bay
item.description: The police are investigating how a 22-year-old man from Kenya got onto the flight, which took off in Johannesburg and stopped in Nairobi.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Arthur Van Der Kooij/Agence France-Presse, via ANP
item.media:description: Schiphol Airport, near Amsterdam. The Dutch police said that they had found a man, alive and in stable condition, in the wheel section of a cargo plane that arrived from South Africa on Sunday.

item.title: A Newly Reported Gathering, and a New Headache for Johnson
item.description: The news came the same day as Mr. Johnson ordered an inquiry into a lawmaker’s claim of Islamophobia.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle

item.title: Benedict Admits Being at Meeting About Priest Accused of Abuse
item.description: A statement by the former pope contradicted a previous statement to a law firm investigating allegations of child sex abuse by priests when he was an archbishop.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Pope Benedict XVI in 2010. A report released last week said the former pope mishandled at least four cases of sexual abuse accusations when he was an archbishop in Germany.

item.title: When It Comes to Investing, Some in Congress Have Oddly Good Timing
item.description: Some members of Congress have strangely good timing when it comes to stock investments.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Senators Richard Burr and Dianne Feinstein sold stocks after a private briefing on Covid-19.

item.title: NATO Steps Up Readiness in Eastern Europe to Reassure Allies
item.description: The alliance is sending more jets and ships to the region. The decision comes as Britain joined the U.S. in withdrawing the families of diplomats in Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier on the frontlines in the city of Avdiivka on Sunday.

item.title: Julian Assange Can Appeal Decision to Extradite Him to U.S., U.K. Court Rules
item.description: The WikiLeaks founder has argued that American prison conditions would be harmful to his mental health. He faces a lengthy sentence if convicted on espionage charges.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Charlie Savage
item.media:description: Supporters of Julian Assange outside the Royal Courts of Justice in London on Monday.

item.title: Can a New Line of Work Help Save These Wild Welsh Ponies?
item.description: A longstanding source of local pride and affection, Welsh mountain ponies have seen many of their traditional roles vanish. A new initiative aims to ensure their continued survival.
item.dc:creator: Claire Thomas
item.media:description: Horses are much-loved pets and companions throughout Wales.

item.title: Germany's Vaccine Mandate Forges Unlikely Coalition of Protestors
item.description: The prospect of a vaccine mandate has galvanized a nationwide protest movement attracting naturalists, neo-Nazis and ordinary citizens alike.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: An anti-vaccine protest in Nuremberg, Germany, this month. Organized resistance to vaccines in Germany is significant, and brings together varying political groups.

item.title: Rich Countries Lure Health Workers From Low-Income Nations to Fight Shortages
item.description: Huge pay incentives and immigration fast-tracks are leading many to leave countries whose health systems urgently need their expertise.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: Alex Mulumba, a nurse at a critical care hospital in Lusaka, Zambia, is considering moving to Canada for better pay. He currently earns $415 per month.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Biden weighs a pivot on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: U.S. soldiers of the NATO Extended Presence Battlegroup participated in a military exercise in Latvia last March.

item.title: U.S. Orders Family Members of Embassy Staff to Leave Ukraine
item.description: The State Department warned that the United States would “not be in a position” to evacuate U.S. citizens should Russia invade.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner, Edward Wong and Lara Jakes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The Ukrainian military at a frontline position in Avdiivka, Donetsk Oblast, on the Russian separatist frontline.

item.title: Thierry Mugler, Genre-Busting French Fashion Designer, Dies at 73
item.description: The dominatrix-loving couturier turned sex into a style weapon.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Bernstein
item.media:description: The designer Manfred Thierry Mugler at his fall 2001 fashion show in Paris.

item.title: Biden Weighs Deploying Thousands of Troops to Eastern Europe and Baltics
item.description: The president is also considering deploying warships and aircraft to NATO allies, in what would be a major shift from its restrained stance on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: U.S. soldiers of the NATO Extended Presence Battlegroup participated in a military exercise in Latvia last March.

item.title: As U.S. Strikes Syria Prison Held by ISIS, Young Detainees Are Caught in Crossfire
item.description: Almost 700 child detainees are being held in the prison still under siege four days after ISIS launched an attack to free detainees
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Syrian Democratic Forces fighters taking position near the prison on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: A U.K. Accusation
item.description: British officials say Russia is trying to establish a pro-Kremlin government in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: French Adventurer Attempting to Row Solo Across the Atlantic Is Missing
item.description: Jean-Jacques Savin, 75, activated distress beacons on Thursday and Friday, his team said. On Saturday, the Portuguese Navy found his boat, but not his body, near the Azores.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:description: Jean-Jacques Savin, 75, who crossed the Atlantic Ocean in a barrel in 2019 before setting off again on January 1, 2022 to row across it, set off his distress beacons on January 21, 2022 and his team has “no further contact” since then, they say on January 22, 2022.
